title: Your Process Isn't What You Think It Is
content:
Most teams think their process is their workflow.

It's not.

Your process is whatever actually happens when work gets done.

And here's what nobody tells you:

If you can't explain it to a system, you don't actually understand it.

You just know that certain people make it work.

→ The person who "just knows" which deals to pursue
→ The person who "has a feel" for what will close
→ The person who "remembers" how to handle edge cases

This isn't a process.

It's tribal knowledge.

And tribal knowledge has a half-life.

When that person leaves, gets busy, or changes roles, the process breaks.

Fast teams are doing something different:

They're extracting the "why" behind the "what."

Not just "We filter by price."

But "We filter by price because X, Y, and Z—and here's when we make exceptions."

When you can articulate the logic, you can:

→ Automate the repetitive parts
→ Scale the judgment parts
→ Preserve the institutional knowledge

The teams winning right now aren't the ones with the best tools.

They're the ones who understand their own operations well enough to know what to keep, what to automate, and what to eliminate.

What's one process in your workflow that only "works" because of one person?
author: Dylan Goren
